content.description: Stand start on your choice of pockets. Use a small foothold to reach a gritty crimp and a big sloper. Topout over the lip. The Brayack guidebook states this one has likely not been climbed frequently, which has lead it to not be climbed frequently. Quality slab movement on solid rock.
content.location: This is the obvious pocketed slab in the back of the Tilted Tree Corridor. It is directly left of the classic Always Dry Roof.

content.description:
Start standing using a jug on the right side of the left arete. Follow the arete through pockets and up the slab to the topout.

This route is #2 on Boulder 1: Pocket Prow Boulder in the Tilted Tree Corridor in the Brayack and Keenan Falcon Guidebook.
content.location: Arete left of Pocket Prow/Bulge

content.description: Stand start using 2 opposing sidepulls and throw to a line of horizontals. Climb the tall face past a left facing sidepull and some slopers to the top. Highball!
content.location: On the right boulder this is the right side of the arete, facing the trail.  It is distinguished by an obvious left facing feature.

content.description:
Start sitting on a sidepull and a sloper with thin feet. Move up following the arete to pockets and ledges at the top or just dyno when the arete becomes a slopey mess.

This route is #12 on Boulder 2 in the Tilted Tree Corridor in the Brayack & Keenan guidebook.
content.location: Arete directly behind the start pocket of pocket prow.

content.description: Personally, my favorite problem in the forest.  Start on an obvious jug and follow the left side of the arete to the top.
content.location: This is the obvious clean arete, on the right front side of the corridor.

content.description: Same start as Two Bagger, then traverse left to Golf Course. The deep mono and big pocket are on.
content.location: The whole backside of the free standing boulder. Starts on the right arete, ends on the left arete.

content.description: Start standing with hands on a big slopey pocket. Find feet, shift your body weight, find a good hand and move up to the good ledge and then go for an easy topout.
content.location: Start is the pocket about 6 ft to the left of the downclimb for this boulder.

content.description: Same start as Tilted Tree Slab Left but at the big pocket go right and up through the pockets to the slopey ledge for an easy topout
content.location: From the main trail, this is the obvious, clean slab into the Tilted Tree Corridor on the left. You can see the Tilted Tree in this Corridor. This route is directly behind Twist Dah Hick and is a variation of the leftmost route on this face.

content.description: Climb the left side of the clean slab, following good pockets and slimpers. Start standing using a sidepull feature. Make a big move to the big pocket and go straight up through the pockets to the ledge and do an easy topout.
content.location: From the main trail, this is the obvious, clean slab into the Tilted Tree Corridor on the left. You can see the Tilted Tree in this Corridor. This route is directly behind Twist Dah Hick and is the leftmost route on this face.

content.description: Start standing with 2 pockets for hands. Using thin feet make long moves through jugs, staying on the left side of the arete.
content.location: Left side of Tilted Tree Arete

content.description: Start standing with 2 pockets for hands. Climb the right side of the arete, making moves through edges to the top out. Be careful and be sure to pad this one well.
content.location: In the back corridor, this is the right arete on the right boulder.  From the main trail, continue down the corridor, this is the right at the end to the right.

content.description: Start on two jugs on the triangular boulder. Follow horizontal through roof, past gap, through slopers to top out.
content.location: Starts to the right of Always Dry Roof

content.description: Begins about 4 ft in from the lip of the roof on an obvious jug.  The jug is on a seemingly detached, pizza slice shaped feature.  Continue through a large pocket, small pocket, then series of edges out the left side of the roof to the top.
content.location: Located in the Snow Globe Area, just to the right and up the hill from inside the Tilted Tree Corridor. This problem is on the front/left side of the roof when looking at the roof from the entrance.

content.description:
Start sitting with a sidepull and crimp for your hands. Work your way up through a protruding handhold, a pocket, and a ledge, finding a key sidepull just to the left of the arete lip. Top out through easy slab staying just to the right of the arete for the whole route.

This is the first route in the Brayack and Keenan Falcon Guidebook.
content.protection: The landing is really bad. Bring a couple pads or better yet don’t climb this unless you’re sure you’re not gonna fall.
content.location: The arete makes up the right side of the chimney that you see on entering the tilted tree corridor. On the main trail face of the pocket prow boulder this chimney splits the boulder at about the halfway point.

content.description:
Start standing using a sloping jug ledge for hands and move up to  the cannonball sized hold. Beta for this varies but it's harder than you'd expect. From here move up through another big pocket and crimp, get feet and grab anything you can below the lip and pull yourself up through the lip to the top-out.

This route is #11 on Boulder 2 in the Tilted Tree Corridor in the Brayack and Keenan Falcon Guidebook.
content.location: From the main trail, there is a cannonball sized pocket on the left side of the left boulder.

content.description: Distinguished by a mono.  Climb the face, past an undercling to a mono and a pocket.
content.location: On the backside of the free standing boulder.  From the main trail, walk through the corridor and turn left.  This problem starts to the right of the "Big Pocket" which is the Big Pocket Problem.

content.description: The crux of this problem is the first move.  If you jump to the starting pocket, its more like a V4 or V5.  Establish on thin pockets and make a hard move to the obvious pocket.  Dig deep, and power through the thin face to the top. CLASSIC
content.location: In the back corridor, the clean pocketed face.

content.description: Start on a large sloper just right of the arete. Move up past edges and pockets to the top staying just right of the arete.
content.location: Left of Big Pocket Problem. This route climbs the just to the right of the arete on the left side of this face.

content.description: One move wonder for sure! Doesn't seem to get a lot of traffic but its just straight up fun! Choose any of the 3 fist sized pockets to start, find your feet, and throw up to the lip. Try not to dab the left wall! Topping out is pretty chill compared to how it looks.
content.location: The first corner to the right of Twist Dah Hick. The climb only uses the right side, not the mossy left part of the corner. Just look for 3 fist-sized pockets, the leftmost one being a mega-jug.

content.description: Sit start on a right edge and a higher left sloping edge on the small overhang.  Make a long move up to the ledge, then finish on the wide crimp rail above it.
content.location: On the right wall of the Final Fantasy cave

content.description: Start is left of Big Pocket Problem on the sloper shared with One Bagger. Shares the same start moves as One Bagger but once you get established with feet on the starting sloper, you can use holds on the left side of the arete to the topout.
content.location: Left of Big Pocket Problem. This route climbs the arete on the left side of this face.

content.description: Start on a jug and climb the obvious crack feature and slopers to the top.
content.location: From the trail, on the left boulder, this problem climbs the obvious crack.

content.description: Must climb those jugs! A little scary but can be done safely.
content.location: Sit start on upper tier boulder to the right of Final Fantasy on the same big roof. For the V7, do a dabby one handed swingin' start from the big undercling to the sloper pinch. For the V6, just start with the left hand on the sloper pinch and the right on the big undercut (less dabby for taller folks). Cling hard through the sloper match and climb through the giant pocket jugs up and left to finish as per Alpha and Omega through the center of the roof feature.

content.description: Start in the same jug as final fantasy. Climb through the reachy crux and instead of exiting the roof early left up the V4, climb straight out the roof to thin crimps and mantle the very end of the roof.
content.location: Big cave in snow globe area

content.description: Start in a HUGE jug facing left with a double toe hook under the roof, and work your way up and over the roof to the left. A complete classic for those with a big reach!
content.location: Located in the Snow Globe Area. After you walk through the Tilted Tree Corridor, turn right past the Always Dry Roof, and continue until you see a roof straight out of a climber's fantasy.

content.description: Sit start using the right arete and a high left crimp for hands (Shared start with Atlas Shrugged). There’s a great starting foot. Move up and left through another crimp and a side pull getting a high foot on a ledge. Pull through the move left and up to a great horizontal before matching the top of the talus to finish the route. This route only uses holds on the talus for hands and feet.
content.location: This route is inside of the cave that holds Roof Problem. This route starts on the right side of the open face of the big climbable talus.

content.description:
Start on the arete with a right slopey pocket and a left fist sized pocket. Use a smeary foot to move up to a hidden sharp jug just below all the moss on the arete. Make another move to the lip and top out. Probably soft for taller people.

This route is #25 on Boulder 3 in the Tilted Tree Corridor area of the Brayack and Keenan falcon guidebook, originally published as a V5.
content.location: The problem starts on the second arete past the tilted tree corridor, this is also the arete right of Occam's Razor.

content.description:
Start on a large left hand pocket and a sloping edge with the right. Move up through sharp sloping holds and a great crystal crimp. Figure out the smeary and flexible foot sequence in order to reach the dirty jugs at the top of the slab. Topout.

The bottom of this slab seems to be always wet. Bring a towel, a brush, and lots of chalk if you are stoked on climbing very sharp and wet slab. You could also wait until it is frozen or hope you find a week of dry weather.
content.protection: A single pad will cover the fall zone, but it gets a little tall at the top.
content.location:
This climb is the barely featured slab in the center of the face on the right side of the tilted tree boulder.

This route is #22 on Boulder 3 in the Tilted Tree Corridor area of the Brayack and Keenan falcon guidebook.

content.description:
Sit start on two horizontal pockets, find your feet and struggle through the top mantle to finish.

This problem is #28 on Boulder 3 in the Tited Tree Corridor of the Brayack and Keenan falcon guidebook. (This problem is on an adjacent boulder to the main Boulder 3)
content.location: In the Tilted Tree Corridor this is the ~4 ft boulder that has the low roof (2 feet off the ground). Facing the arete of this boulder the start of this problem is about 3 feet left of the arete.

content.description: Sit start on the low sloper.  Figure out your foot beta and huck for the slopey lip and top out.
content.location: On the right side of the arete on the small boulder straight ahead after walking past the tilted tree.

content.description: A great compression problem. Start sitting using low hands on either side of the face. Make several tricky moves and slap up the sides to stand. Once standing you can either jump for the top or continue slapping your way up. Top out and step up over other boulders to get back to solid ground to walk down. The tempting rocks to the left and right of this face are off.
content.location: From the main trail leading to the Tilted Tree Corridor, continue along the trailside faces of the corridor and then passed the main corridor faces until you reach a shorter, detached rectangular boulder with other boulders stacked on top of it (This boulder is under a large roof that would appear to be the outer back end of the boulder that Roof Problem and Final Fantasy are on. Those routes are on the inside, this route is outside and on a lower tier).

content.description: Sit-start and follow the compression arete to the top.  A really good problem that can sometimes be green.
content.location: Located in the back corridor of the area, walk through the corridor from the trail, turning left.  Continue past the boulder on your left, spotting the obvious slopers and compression arete in front of you.

content.description: Start on your choice of good holds and follow the left side of the arete to the top.  Pretty good problem.
content.location: The arete across from Twist Dah Hick, and the obvious arete on the left side of the corridor.

content.description: Start just below and to the right of the large pocket in the center of the face on pocket and pinch. Go straight up through the large pocket to the cruxy smaller pockets and an easy topout.
content.location: On the back side of the free standing boulder.  From the main trail, walk through the corridor, turning left.  This problem is distinguished by a...well big pocket.  F

content.description: Starting on juggy pockets in the back of the cave, climb to the starting jug of Final Fantasy, and finish on it, exiting the roof out the left side. The only downfall of this line is that the finish is frequently wet. Otherwise, it’s really unique and enjoyable climbing on horizontal terrain.
content.location: Start in the back of the “Final Fantasy Roof” in the Snow Globe area next to Tilted Tree corridor

content.description: This is an extension of the already established line “The Beginning of the End” V9. Climb from the back of the “Final Fantasy Roof” to a large triangular jug . Instead of bailing left and finishing on the V4 “Roof problem”, continue directly out the roof, climbing past a couple crimps and a foot cut, and top out right in the center.  This straightens out the original line, and is arguably the more obvious line out the roof, but it likely adds a grade due to the harder finish.
content.location: In the “Final Fantasy Roof” at Tilted Tree

content.description:
Sit start on two pockets and move through a good horizontal. Finish by matching on the roof.

This problem is #5 on Boulder 1: Pocket Prow boulder in the Tilted Tree Corridor of the Brayack and Keenan falcon guidebook. (This boulder is actually on the boulder just to the climber's right of the Pocket Prow face of the Pocket Prow boulder.)
content.location: This boulder is opposite the Always Dry Roof and right beside the Pocket Prow Boulder. The route is on the right side of the face and starts just to the left of the arete.

content.description: Sit start using the right arete and a high left crimp for hands (Shared start with The Fate of Atlas). There’s a great starting foot. Move up and left to another crimp. From here find whatever position you can to move up and right to another crimp. Get a high foot and match the top of the talus to finish. Everything left of the seam is off for both hands and feet for this route (including the foot ledge). As well, this route only uses holds on the talus for hands and feet.
content.location: This route is inside of the cave that holds Roof Problem. This route starts on the right side of the open face of the big climbable talus.

content.description: A beautiful hand crack formed by the two boulders.  Start on the horizontal and slab and follow the roof crack, finishing by traversing off right.
content.location: This is located in the horizontal roof in the back of the area.  Walk through the corridor, turn left, the look right.

content.description: Likely the best line in the cave. And no...it’s not an eliminate. Climb “The Beginning of the End” to the triangular jug, and continue out the roof, aiming up and right to a series of jug rails. This line is the longest line in the cave, and stays completely dry in the rain, as opposed to the original finish and direct finish, which are soaking wet the majority of the time. Because of this, it is generally the most logical line to take. Basically, instead of exiting the roof via the V4 “Roof Problem”, you tack on a unique V4/5 on bigger holds with a nice, comfortable top out. Classic!
content.location: This is the far right exit to “The Beginning AND the End” in the “Final Fantasy Roof”
